This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the mayor and council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-36. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of executions for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in full [force] until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-37. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the city administrator and the police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the municipal court judge. It is hereby made the further duty of the city administrator, chief of police, members of the police department, and their assistants, to inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-38. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by mayor and council. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the mayor and council. All provisions heretofore relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-39. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. 
After January 1, 1996, the mayor and council shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-40. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
The mayor and council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one (1) or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selective types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reason shall be set forth in the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-41. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-42. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to effect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Sec. 12-43. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 95-04, § 1, 12-4-95) 
Secs. 12-44, 12-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BILLIARD ROOMS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Billiard rooms generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-1 et seq.; municipal regulation of billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-6. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-46. - Purpose of article. 
(a)	This article has been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the purpose, among others, of promoting the health and general welfare of the city, to establish reasonable controls and ascertainable standards for the operation, regulation and control of billiard rooms, to give effect to existing land use, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining neighborhood and property values. 
(b)	This article shall not apply to those establishments maintaining no more than one (1) coin-operated pool table which has been previously licensed as a coin-operated device under Article IV, Coin-Operated Devices. 
(Code 1977, § 6-20; Ord. No. 90-12, 10-1-90) 
Sec. 12-47. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, definitions shall be the same as those utilized and contained within O.C.G.A. Section 48-8-1 except as may be contained and defined elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 6-21) 
Sec. 12-48. - Compliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, control, own, frequent or enter any billiard room without having complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 6-22) 
Sec. 12-49. - Employees. 
(a)	No person shall be employed by any establishment holding any license under this article until such person has been issued a certificate of eligibility by the police department. 
(b)	All persons subject to the provisions of this article shall, within seventy-two (72) hours after the date of their first work in an establishment, report to the police department for fingerprinting. 
(c)	All persons reporting to the police department may be required to fill out a personal history statement for the purposes of an investigation into their eligibility for employment. 
(d)	The police department shall make a search relative to the police record of the person fingerprinted. The commission of a felony, and the conviction thereon shall act as a complete bar to employment in an establishment licensed under this article. The conviction for misdemeanors shall likewise act as a bar if they are of such numbers or of such types as to indicate that the individual has a bad reputation. 
(e)	The police department shall either issue a certificate or shall inform the license holder and the prospective employee why the certificate cannot be issued. 
(f)	The licensee may appeal an adverse finding to the municipal court. 
(g)	The police department may, from time to time, and as additional information becomes available, review issued certificates and may, as circumstances dictate, withdraw and/or suspend certificates for cause. Adverse findings may likewise be appealed to the municipal court. 
(h)	The licensee shall pay a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee to the police department before employment of any individual. Such fee shall be utilized to pay the costs of the police investigation. 
(Code 1977, § 6-23) 
Sec. 12-50. - Alcoholic beverages. 
It shall be unlawful to sell, serve or allow the use of alcoholic beverages in or on the premises of any business licensed under this article unless such premises or establishment derives at least fifty-one (51) percent of its total annual gross revenues from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1977, § 6-24; Ord. No. 92-04, § 1, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 12-51. - Hours for operation of billiard rooms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard room between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. or to permit any person to remain in such billiard room between such prohibited hours, except regular employees performing necessary labor on the premises. 
(Code 1977, § 6-25) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-9. 
Sec. 12-52. - Sanitary regulations; immoral conduct, betting, etc. 
(a)	All licensed premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to permit, participate in, and/or encourage any disturbance of the peace, or immoral conduct, or betting or wagering on any licensed premises. 
(Code 1977, § 6-26) 
State Law reference— Sanitation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-7; gambling on premises, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-12. 
Sec. 12-53. - Frequenting by minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any operator, owner or employee of any business licensed under or operating under this article to allow or permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter or remain within the confines of said business unless that person is either accompanied by a parent or legal guardian or shall have obtained a notarized authorization, upon forms to be supplied by the city police department, from either a parent or legal guardian. 
(Code 1977, § 6-27) 
Sec. 12-54. - Ordering temporary closing. 
Temporary closings and/or suspensions of license for reasons of public safety may be ordered by the mayor, city recorder, or chief of police. Such order shall have a duration of not more than five (5) days and shall be issued for good cause only. 
(Code 1977, § 6-28) 
Secs. 12-55—12-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-71. - Required. 
No billiard room shall be opened or operated except under a license granted by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 6-35) 
Sec. 12-72. - Status of license; subject to laws, etc. 
All licenses granted under this division shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license and subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by the city charter, and related laws, applicable provisions of this Code, other ordinances, and state, county and federal laws and regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 6-36) 
Sec. 12-73. - Division subject to change. 
(a)	This division may be modified in whole or in part, and at any time, and all persons seeking or holding licenses are hereby notified that they may be affected by changes to this division that might in the future occur. 
(b)	All persons are expressly placed on notice that any license granted under this division shall be and is a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article, and that this article is subject to modification and that they are subject to any modification thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 6-37) 
Sec. 12-74. - Application form, content. 
All persons desiring to obtain a license under this division shall make a written application to the city for such privilege upon forms to be prepared and approved by the governing body. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the proposed location of the business, the nature and character of the business to be carried on, proof of compliance with state license laws, proof of ownership of county license, and such other information as may be required by the governing body. 
(Code 1977, § 6-38) 
Sec. 12-75. - Investigation of application, report. 
All applications required under this division shall be investigated by the police department. The police department shall file its report with the police committee. 
(Code 1977, § 6-39) 
Sec. 12-76. - Disqualifying circumstances—General. 
No license shall be granted under this division where the application, investigation by the police department, or the evidence on a hearing shows any of the following conditions to exist: 
(1)	That the applicant is of bad moral character or has a bad reputation in the community, or does not have sufficient mental capacity to conduct the business for which the application is made. 
(2)	That the applicant has had a license for a similar establishment suspended or revoked within the five-year period next preceding the date of application unless such applicant can show that such suspension was lifted or unless such revocation was lifted and the license later restored. 
(3)	That the applicant has been convicted of more than one (1) misdemeanor within the five-year period next preceding the date of application. Minor traffic violations shall not be considered in the determination of the aforementioned misdemeanors. A conviction of a misdemeanor shall include the adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty or the forfeiture of a bond of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more. Violations of city ordinances shall be considered misdemeanors for the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 6-40; Ord. No. 92-04, § 2, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 12-77. - Same—Felony conviction; dishonorable military discharge. 
No license shall be issued under this division to any person who shall have been convicted of any felony, nor to any person who shall have received a dishonorable discharge from the armed forces of the United States. 
(Code 1977, § 6-41) 
Sec. 12-78. - Same—Denial for false information in application. 
Any material omission, or any untrue statement contained in an original or renewal application for a license under this division shall furnish grounds for denial thereof or sufficient grounds for revocation thereof as the case may be. 
(Code 1977, § 6-42) 
Sec. 12-79. - Issuance of license limited to designated areas. 
No license shall be issued to any person for the operation of a business except in properly zoned areas. 
(Code 1977, § 6-43) 
Sec. 12-80. - Fee—Setting annually. 
The annual license fee for licenses issued under this division shall be set by the governing body during the month of December of each year. Such fee shall be applied during the following year. Should the governing body not set a rate for any year then the fee to be charged shall continue at the rate set for the preceding year. 
(Code 1977, § 6-44) 
Sec. 12-81. - Same—Payment. 
All annual license fees under this division shall be paid on or before February 15th of each year. Any new license granted hereunder shall require the full fee. 
(Code 1977, § 6-45; Ord. No. 92-04, § 3, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 12-82. - Same—No refund in event of revocation. 
In the event of revocation, no refund of any kind, or of any part of any license fee issued under this division shall be made. 
(Code 1977, § 6-46) 
Sec. 12-83. - Investigation, report and approval prerequisite to issuance. 
All applications for a license under this division shall be investigated by the police department, shall be reported to the police committee, and favorably acted upon by the governing body before the city administrator shall be authorized to issue any license under this division. 
(Code 1977, § 6-47) 
Sec. 12-84. - Time for obtaining license after approval. 
All licenses required by this division must be obtained and all fees paid within thirty (30) days of approval of application by the governing body. 
(Code 1977, § 6-48) 
Sec. 12-85. - Transfer of license. 
No license granted under this division shall be transferred. 
(Code 1977, § 6-49) 
Sec. 12-86. - Annual renewal. 
(a)	All businesses operating under this division shall be required to renew their licenses annually, by February 15th of each year, upon the forms prescribed by the governing body. 
(b)	Prior to renewal, all persons holding licenses and requesting renewal thereof shall obtain the required county license and shall display such county license to the city administrator at the time the application for renewal is submitted. 
(Code 1977, § 6-50; Ord. No. 92-04, § 4, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 12-87. - Suspension and revocation—Authorized. 
All licenses granted under this division are subject to revocation and/or suspension by either the governing body or by the municipal court. 
(Code 1977, § 6-51) 
Sec. 12-88. - Same—Conditions; grounds. 
(a)	No license issued by the city under this division shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing and upon five (5) days' written notice to the holder of such license of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a statement of the charge or charges upon which the hearing shall be held. 
(b)	"Due cause" for the suspension or for the revocation of any license issued under this division shall consist of the violation of any law or ordinance regulating such business, or the violation of any state or federal law, or the violation of any city ordinance, other than traffic ordinances, or the falsification, by either material omission or untrue statement, of any application, or information in obtaining any license or the renewal thereof. 
(c)	The hearing for determination of grounds for suspension or revocation shall be held by the municipal court with appeal therefrom to the governing body. 
(Code 1977, § 6-52) 
Sec. 12-89. - Same—Automatic revocation upon revocation of county license. 
Whenever the county shall revoke any county license the comparable city license is thereby revoked. It shall be necessary to have all required county licenses in order to hold a valid city license. 
(Code 1977, § 6-53) 
Secs. 12-90—12-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COIN-OPERATED DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-106. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Arcade room shall mean any establishment where more than three (3) coin-operated amusement machines are placed or kept for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play by the general public. 
Arcade room proprietor shall mean any proprietor of an arcade room. As used herein, the terms "proprietor" and "arcade room proprietor" shall be synonymous unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Coin-operated amusement machine shall mean any machine or device operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, or similar object, for the purpose of receiving the temporary services of such machine for recreation or a game of skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged. The term includes coin-operated electronic games, pinball machines, and other similar devices. The term does not include vending machines in which are not incorporated recreation features, nor does the term include any coin-operated mechanical musical devices or kiddie rides. As used herein the terms "machine" and "coin-operated amusement machine" shall be synonymous unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Distributor shall mean any person who sets up for operation by another and leases or rents for the purpose of operation by another, any machine as herein regulated, whether such leasing or renting be for a fixed charge or rental, or on the basis of a division of the income derived from such device, or otherwise. 
Proprietor shall mean any person who, as the owner or lessee, has under his control any establishment, place or premises in or at which a coin-operated amusement machine is placed or kept for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play by the general public. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-54, 3-9-82) 
Secs. 12-107—12-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-121. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the business of a distributor or proprietor of coin-operated amusement machines without first having obtained the proper license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-55, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-122. - Application. 
(a)	Application for license under this division shall be filed in writing with the city administrator, on a form to be provided by the city, and shall specify: 
(1)	The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses. 
(2)	Proprietors shall list the address of the premises where the licensed machine or machines are to be operated, together with the character of the business as carried on at such place. 
(3)	Proprietors shall list the number of machines to be maintained on the premises. 
(4)	Proprietors shall list the name and address of the owner and/or distributor of the machine or machines, if other than the proprietor. 
(5)	Distributors shall list the names and addresses of all proprietors within the city on whose premises the distributor has installed, placed or assigned such machines and shall list the total number of machines at each location. 
(6)	Whether or not the person having management of or supervision over the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense, and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(7)	The information contained within this application shall not be released to the general public without the consent of the licensee. 
(b)	The proper license fee shall accompany the application. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-59, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-123. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-02, adopted January 4, 1999, amended the Code by repealing former § 12-123 in its entirety. Former § 12-123 pertained to fees, and derived from Ord. No. 82-2, adopted March 9, 1982; and Ord. No. 94-05, adopted December 5, 1994. 
Sec. 12-124. - Character qualifications. 
No license shall be issued under this division to or renewed for any person who has or employs a person who has, within five (5) years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving drug-related offenses or offenses involving moral turpitude. The licensee will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the city on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information shall be forwarded to the police department for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications be fulfilled, prior to the issuance or renewal of any license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-60, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-125. - Increasing number of devices. 
In case a proprietor licensed under the provisions of this division desires, after the expiration of any portion of any license year, to increase the number of machines to be used or played, or exhibited for use or play in his establishment, so that he then has three (3) or more machines, he shall surrender his license to the city administrator who shall issue a new arcade room proprietor license upon payment of the proper license fee therefor with any applicable credit for the previously paid license fee. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-61, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-126. - Assignment, transfer. 
The license required by this division shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and in the case of a proprietor shall apply only to the premises for which such license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-59, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-127. - Display; identification of machine. 
The license issued under this division shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the establishment of the licensee. In addition, each machine shall have placed upon it by the licensee a sticker showing the license number of its distributor and/or proprietor. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-59, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-128. - Revocation. 
In the event that it comes to the attention of the governing body that the amusement machine in question has created a nuisance to the surrounding community or has violated any provision of this article, the following procedure will be followed: 
(1)	The chief of police shall issue a notice of objection which shall include the address of the location and the specific reasons why the machine or machines in question are alleged to be a nuisance or alleged to violate any provision of this article. The chief of police will then notify the proprietor that a notice of objection has been filed and will set a date for a hearing before the governing body on this matter. Extensions and necessary investigations will be granted and conducted at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(2)	At the time of the hearing, any resident, the distributor, the proprietor and the chief of police may be heard. After this hearing the governing body shall issue a "notice of decision" which will call for the dismissal of the objection, removal of the machines or such other remedy as they deem appropriate under the circumstances that are consistent with the purpose of this article. 
(3)	The decision of the governing body shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for their decision and shall be based upon the merits of the case. 
(4)	The decision of the governing body shall be final but may be appealed to the appropriate court within thirty (30) days. 
(5)	The decision of the governing body shall be binding upon the proprietor and distributor of the machine under consideration. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-62, 3-9-82) 
Secs. 12-129—12-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OPERATIONAL RULES 

Sec. 12-141. - Conformance to division. 
All businesses licensed under this article shall be subject to the provisions of this division. Violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be sufficient grounds for revocation of a license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63, 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-142. - Inspection. 
The chief of police shall inspect or cause the inspection of any place or building in which any such machine or machines are operated or set up for operation and to inspect, investigate and test such machines as needed. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(b), 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-143. - Devices to be kept in plain view; gambling devices prohibited. 
(a)	All machines coming under this article shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of and open and accessible to any person who may frequent or be in any place of business where such machines are kept or used. However, no machine shall be placed within five (5) feet of any public entrance or exit and no proprietor, except arcade room proprietors may keep or maintain a machine between any public entrance or exit and any cash register. 
(b)	Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize, permit or license any gambling device of any nature whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(a), 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-144. - Attendant required. 
It shall be unlawful for any proprietor to open his business to the public unless an attendant is present. The attendant shall be of sufficient mental and physical capacity so as to be able to provide aid to patrons if needed or desired. Such attendant shall not be less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(c), 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-145. - Refunds and adjustments. 
Refunds and adjustments to all customers shall be the responsibility of the proprietor of the machine in question. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(d), 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-146. - Loitering. 
(a)	As used in this section, "loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one (1) location and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, or walking about aimlessly, and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around." 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter within the immediate vicinity of any machine or business premises regulated under this article or for any person licensed to operate an arcade room to permit loitering on or in the immediate vicinity of any machine or business premises regulated hereunder in such a manner as to: 
(1)	Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace; 
(2)	Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person; 
(3)	Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
(4)	Obstruct, molest, or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(e), 3-9-82) 
Sec. 12-147. - Alcoholic beverages. 
No proprietor shall allow alcoholic beverages to be brought onto their premises by any person. 
(Ord. No. 82-2, § 6-63(f), 3-9-82) 
Secs. 12-148—12-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PAWNBROKERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; authority to regulate pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-135, 44-12-136. 

Sec. 12-166. - License. 
(a)	No person shall conduct business as a pawnbroker, or maintain an establishment for the purposes of conducting business as a pawnbroker, until a business license has been obtained from the city administrator. Such license application shall be made to the city administrator and license issued only upon approval by the governing body. 
(b)	No action on any application for pawnbroker's license shall be taken until the chief of police has reviewed and investigated such application and forwarded his recommendation thereon to the governing body for its consideration, approval, or denial. 
(c)	No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person or to any pawnbroker who employs anyone who has been convicted of any crime involving as an element thereof the theft of property. 
(d)	The annual regulatory fee for each pawnbroker doing business within the city or for each individual establishment maintained for the purpose of doing business as a pawnbroker within the city shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A schedule of regulatory fees imposed by the city shall be on file with the city clerk. 
(e)	Any person violating any subsection of this section shall be subject to revocation of his license to do business. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, §§ 6-64—6-67, 6-72; Ord. No. 2015-03, § 2, 3-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-167. - Hours of operation. 
A pawnbroker shall not conduct business in the city except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. or sundown, whichever occurs first, Monday through Saturday. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-67, 2-6-84) 
Sec. 12-168. - Records. 
(a)	Each pawnbroker licensed under this article shall furnish to the chief of police each week a list of every item pledged with him or sold to him during the previous week. Such list may be a copy of the information required to be kept by O.C.G.A. § 44-12-132 or any other list maintained containing the same information as follows: 
(1)	The date of transaction. 
(2)	The name of the person conducting the transaction. 
(3)	The name, age and address of the customer, a description of the general appearance of the customer and a distinctive number from the customer's driver's license. In the event the customer has no valid driver's license, the pawnbroker shall make and retain a photograph of such customer. 
(4)	An identification and description of the pledged or purchased goods, including, if reasonably available, the serial, model or other number, and all identifying marks inscribed thereon. 
(5)	The number of the receipt or pawn ticket. 
(6)	The price paid or the amount loaned. 
(7)	The number of the check issued for the purchase price or loan if payment is made by check. 
(8)	The maturity date of the transaction. 
(9)	The signature of the customer. 
(b)	Entries shall appear in chronological order in ink. No blank lines may be left between entries. No obliterations, alterations, or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. The book shall be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer during the ordinary hours of business, or at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-68, 2-6-84) 
State Law reference— Records, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-132 et seq. 
Sec. 12-169. - Thumbprints. 
Any pawnbroker who shall receive as a pledge or purchase any item, good or ware valued in excess of ten dollars ($10.00) or any revolver, pistol, shotgun, rifle or any other firearm shall be required to take a thumbprint of such person pledging or selling any of the above items. Such thumbprints must be kept by the pawnbroker as part of the records required by the state and for the period of time required therein. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-69, 2-6-84) 
Sec. 12-170. - Minors. 
No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker's license be issued to a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker employ a minor to assist him in his business. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-70, 2-6-84) 
State Law reference— Records, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-132 et seq. 
Sec. 12-171. - Stolen goods. 
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him or which is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe the article was stolen, or lost and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. No pawnbroker shall accept any item, good or ware upon which a manufacturer's identity or serial number has been removed, obliterated, or in any way caused to become unreadable. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-71, 2-6-84) 
Sec. 12-172. - Certain purchased articles to be held thirty days. 
Any pawnbroker or person operating under a pawnbroker's license who purchases goods, other than those purchased through wholesalers or on order in the normal course of business, taking full title thereto (the word "goods" being used in the broadest sense and including all kinds of personal property) shall hold such goods purchased for at least thirty (30) days before disposing of same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 6-72, 2-6-84) 
Secs. 12-173—12-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PRIVATE DETECTIVES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Commercial guard or security dogs, § 5-60. 
State Law reference— Georgia Private Detective Business and Private Security Agencies Act, O.C.G.A. § 43-38-1 et seq.; local ordinances authorized, O.C.G.A. § 43-38-14(c). 

Sec. 12-191. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, the words "private detectives" or "private detective agencies" are defined as those following the business or vocation pursued by all persons or agencies making investigations for others when the investigations involve the conduct, life or affairs of the persons investigated. These terms shall not include lawyers and accountants in the course of their practice or incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 89-03, § 6-74, 2-6-89) 
Sec. 12-192. - Annual licensing. 
(a)	Any person wishing to engage in the business of private detective or private detective agency shall make the initial application, pay the license fee and be granted an initial license prior to beginning any detective work in the city. Initial licenses shall expire on December thirty-first of the year in which they are granted. Thereafter the person shall make application for continuance of the business in the city annually on or before January first for license for the coming year. The procedure on the application shall be followed as was followed on the original application. A separate license must be obtained for each person engaged in activities described herein even though that person is an employee of another person duly licensed under this section. 
(b)	Any person who shall desire to engage in the business of a private detective or detective agency shall first make application to the chief of police and the application shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The name of the applicant, his age and present address. 
(2)	The places the applicant has resided in the past ten (10) years. 
(3)	The places the applicant has been employed for the past ten (10) years. 
(4)	The marital status of the applicant. 
(5)	Information concerning the experience the applicant has had in detective work. 
(6)	Information concerning the applicant's criminal record, if any. 
(7)	The names and addresses of two (2) residents of the state for character purposes. 
(8)	The names and addresses of two (2) credit references. 
(9)	Any other information the chief of police deems pertinent. 
The application shall be accompanied by a photograph not more than twelve (12) months old of the applicant. 
The application shall be made under oath and the giving of false information shall result in the revocation of any license issued in reliance thereon. 
(c)	It shall be the duty of the chief of police to accept each application presented to him as set out above. The chief shall then investigate the character, integrity and competence of the applicant. The chief shall then submit a written report to the city administrator together with recommendations for the issuance or denial of the license. The city administrator shall report to the governing body at the next regular meeting. The governing body shall determine the merits of the matter and either direct the issuance of the license or deny the same. 
(d)	No person shall be granted a license as a private detective unless that person has attained twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(e)	The annual regulatory fee for each person shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-03, §§ 6-75—6-80, 2-6-89; Ord. No. 94-05, § 8, 12-5-94) 
State Law reference— State license as prerequisite, O.C.G.A. § 43-38-14.1. 
Sec. 12-193. - Police supervision. 
All private detectives shall be subject to supervision and direction by police officers of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-03, § 6-81, 2-6-89) 
Sec. 12-194. - Regulations and prohibited activities. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to allow any person licensed hereunder to violate the laws of the United States, the state, or the city, nor shall any person licensed hereunder violate the civil or constitutional rights of any person nor shall any person licensed under this article use the license, credentials, or position to collect money or obtain property from any person. Should the city administrator receive a complaint from any person that a licensee has violated any provision of this section, he shall within thirty (30) days of receiving the complaint set up a hearing before the governing body and give the person against whom the complaint was made fifteen (15) days' notice of the hearing. At the hearing the mayor or, in his absence, the mayor pro tem shall preside. Both the complaining party and the person against whom the complaint is made shall be entitled to counsel of their choice; to subpoena and call witnesses; and be heard on the merits. Witnesses shall testify under oath and be subject to penalty for perjury if false testimony is given. The purpose of the hearing shall be to determine the fitness of the person against whom the complaint is made to continue to operate as a private detective in the city. After hearing evidence from both sides, the governing body shall vote "yes" or "no," to continue the license. If a majority of the governing body present and voting, vote "no," the license shall be thereupon revoked. No person whose license has been revoked shall be allowed to reapply for a license within twelve (12) months of the revocation. 
(Ord. No. 89-03, § 6-82, 2-6-89) 
Secs. 12-195—12-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SOLID WASTE HANDLERS 

Sec. 12-211. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, the definition of solid waste shall be the same as defined within Article V of Chapter 24. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Sec. 12-212. - License required. 
No person shall conduct business as a solid waste handler within the city without first obtaining a business license from the city administrator in the manner specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Sec. 12-213. - Fee established. 
The annual business license fee for each solid waste handler doing business within the city shall be set from time to time as deemed appropriate by the governing body. Current schedules of such license fees shall be kept on file in the city administrator's office. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Sec. 12-214. - Application. 
All persons desiring to obtain a license under this article shall submit an initial written application, and a renewal application annually thereafter, to the city for such privilege upon forms to be approved by the governing body. Such applications shall state the name and address of the applicant, the location or proposed location of the business, the service area of the business, proof of compliance with state license laws and with city ordinances (particularly with Article V of Chapter 24 of the city code), proof of ownership of county license, if required, and such other information as may be required by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Sec. 12-215. - Letters of assurance required. 
(a)	In addition to the information required of an applicant for a solid waste handler's license, each initial and renewal application must also include a letter of solid waste disposal assurance from a state-permitted solid waste disposal facility. The letter must be on the letterhead of the entity owning the disposal facility and must contain the following information: 
(1)	Name and address of the solid waste disposal facility to be utilized by the applicant. 
(2)	Name, address and telephone number of the entity to whom the state permit is issued. 
(3)	Name, title and telephone number of the authorized individual or company official signing the assurance letter on behalf of the disposal facility. 
(4)	Estimated life of permitted capacity remaining at current and projected rates of waste disposal in tons or cubic yards. 
(5)	A statement that sufficient disposal capacity exists to accommodate the solid waste handling applicant over the expected remaining life of the disposal facility based on the remaining capacity and the amount of waste received at the disposal facility. 
(6)	A statement that appropriate arrangements are in place such that the disposal facility will reserve a portion of its capacity on behalf of the solid waste handler license applicant. 
(b)	In the event the proposed disposal facility has a remaining life of less than ten (10) years, the license application must include additional letters of solid waste disposal assurance containing the above-described information such that a total of ten (10) years of disposal assurance is provided. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Sec. 12-216. - Compliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, control, manage or own any business which handles solid waste within the city without having complied with the provisions of this article. Noncompliance shall subject such a violator to the revocation of any business license which may have been issued pursuant to this article, and to a fine and/or imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, 1-4-93) 
Secs. 12-217—12-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BAIL BONDSMEN[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 93-03, adopted Feb. 1, 1993, added provisions designated as Ch. 2, Art. VII, §§ 12-211—12-216. To avoid duplicative section numbering, such provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 2, Art. VIII, §§ 12-221—12-228 at the discretion of the editor. Subsequently, Ord. No. 93-04, §§ 1—4, adopted June 7, 1993, set out provisions intended to amend Ch. 2, Art. VIII, §§ 12-212 and 12-214; these provisions were applied to §§ 12-222 and 12-224 due to the renumbering indicated above. 

Sec. 12-221. - Annual licensing. 
(a)	Any person wishing to engage in the business of a bail bondsman must first obtain a county license, complete the initial application, submit any required paperwork or documentation, pay the license fee, and then be approved for the initial license by the mayor and council prior to conducting business or operating within the city. Initial licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year in which they are granted. 
(b)	All licensees operating under this article shall be required to renew their licenses annually during the month of January of each year, following the same procedure for the renewal application as was required for the original application. Prior to renewal, all license holders shall obtain the required county license and shall display such county license to the city administrator at the time the application for renewal is submitted. 
(c)	The annual license fee for licenses issued under this article shall be set from time to time by the mayor and council as they deem appropriate, and a schedule of such fees shall be kept current and maintained on file in the city administrator's office. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 12-222. - Application. 
(a)	Application under this article shall be completed in writing, verified, and filed with the city administrator, on a form to be provided by the city, and shall contain the following: 
(1)	Name and home address of the applicant. 
(2)	If the business is to be owned or operated by a corporation, partnership, or association, the names and home addresses of the owners, partners, shareholders, officers and directors. 
(3)	The social security numbers, driver's license numbers, and dates of birth of the applicant and all owners, partners, shareholders, officers and directors. 
(4)	Address and telephone number of the premises where the proposed business is to be located. 
(b)	The following documents must be attached as exhibits to the application: 
(1)	Certified documentation evidencing the county sheriff's approval of the applicant to conduct business as a bail bondsman, or a certified copy of the county license to conduct business as a bail bondsman. 
(2)	The surety bond, or proof of an approved and accepted alternative form of security as a substitution thereof, as required under section 12-224. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 93-04, § 1, 6-7-93) 
Sec. 12-223. - Investigation of applicant, owner, etc. 
All applicants, owners, partners, shareholders, officers and directors applying for a license under this article shall be investigated by the chief of police within ten (10) business days following the applicant's submission of the application to the city administrator. The chief of police will then forward the application along with his recommendation to the mayor and council for consideration and action at their next regularly-scheduled public meeting. No license shall be granted prior to approval by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 12-224. - Surety required. 
(a)	Applicants for a license under this article shall file a surety bond with the city administrator binding the surety to the city in an amount up to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) issued by a surety company that is acceptable to and approved by the city administrator. No license shall be granted under this article prior to submission of the surety bond and approval of the surety company by the city administrator. 
(b)	A liability insurance policy or a letter of credit payable to the city in the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), which has been issued by an insurance company or a financial institution, respectively, authorized to do business in the state and approved by the city administrator, may be permitted by the mayor and council in their discretion in lieu of the surety bond herein required. Alternatively, real property with a fair market value of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), free and clear of any liens, and remaining lien-free throughout the existence of the business, may be posted to the city as security, if acceptable by the mayor and council in their discretion, in lieu of the surety bond, liability insurance policy, or letter of credit. 
(c)	In addition, the city shall have the right to demand additional surety depending on the circumstances and in the discretion of the city administrator and/or the municipal court judge. The surety amount may also be raised from time to time, as the city administrator and/or the municipal court judge deem appropriate, based upon the number and amount of outstanding bonds issued by any particular business licensed hereunder. 
(d)	Any security submitted pursuant to this section, whether in the form of surety bonds, insurance policies, letters of credit, or real property, shall be held by the city for a minimum period of twelve (12) months after the business is terminated. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 93-04, §§ 2—4, 6-7-93) 
Sec. 12-225. - Suspension and revocation; authorized. 
All licenses granted under this article are subject to revocation and/or suspension by either the mayor and council or by the municipal court, subject to constitutional due process. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 12-226. - Transfer of license. 
No license granted under this article shall be transferred. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 12-227. - Automatic revocation upon revocation of county license. 
Whenever the county shall revoke any county bondsman license the city bondsman license is thereby revoked. It shall be necessary to have all required county licenses in order to hold a valid city license. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Sec. 12-228. - Penalty for noncompliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, control or own any bail bondsman business without having complied with the provisions of this article. Any noncompliance shall subject the license holder to revocation of the business license, and/or fines and/or imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, 2-1-93) 
Secs. 12-229, 12-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TATTOO ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 12-231. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases when used herein shall be construed as follows: 
Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form indelible marks or figures or by the production of scars; provided, however, that the word "tattoo" shall not mean a tattoo placed upon the skin by a physician for medical identification purposes. 
Tattoo artist means any person who actually performs the work of tattooing. 
Tattoo establishment means any room or place where tattooing is practiced or where the business of tattooing is conducted or any part thereof. 
Tattoo operator means any person who controls, operates, conducts or manages any tattoo establishment, whether actually performing the work of tattooing or not. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-232. - License required. 
No person shall operate a tattoo establishment or engage in the practice or business of tattooing as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist unless and until the person has first secured a license to do so from the city. Each application for a license to engage in the practice or business of tattooing as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall include payment of an investigative fee and an annual license fee in amounts to be determined by the governing body from time to time in a separate ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-233. - Application. 
Any person desiring to operate a tattoo establishment or desiring to operate as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall make application for a permit to the police department, on forms supplied by that department. The minimum age of each applicant shall be eighteen (18) years of age. Fingerprints of all applicants shall be taken by the bureau. Applicants for permits shall also furnish to the detective bureau two (2) photographs showing a front and side picture of the full face of the applicant, size two and one-half (2½) inches by two and three-fourths (2¾) inches. Applicants for permits shall present to the bureau a medical certificate from a medical doctor certifying that the person is sound physically, mentally, has good eyesight and is not infected with a disease which can be communicated through openings in the human skin. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-234. - License issued in name of applicant; nontransferable. 
All licenses granted shall be issued in the name of the individual person applying therefor, shall contain the location of the tattoo establishment where the applicant shall operate and shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-235. - Tattooing certain persons prohibited. 
No tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall tattoo any person who is a minor, any person who is under either the influence of alcohol, drugs or other stimulants, or depressants or any person of unsound mind. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-236. - Grounds for revocation of license. 
Any person who shall conduct a tattoo establishment or engage in the business as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist without first securing a license therefor or who shall knowingly violate any of the sections of this article shall subject the license to revocation upon appropriate notice of hearing. An artist's or operator's license shall be subject to revocation upon proof that the holder of the permit has become infected with a disease which can be communicated through openings in the human skin. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-237. - Location restricted. 
No permit shall issue for the operation of a tattoo establishment or to any person engaged as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist in any area which is zoned for residential use by the zoning ordinance of the city as it may now or hereafter exist. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-238. - License not in lieu of occupation tax certificate. 
The licenses issued hereunder shall be cumulative and not in lieu of any occupation tax certificate issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 2, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 12-239. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ENERGY EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 12-240. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Palmetto Excise Tax Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-241. - Findings and intent. 
This article is adopted to address the interest of public finance. Georgia law authorizes counties and municipalities to impose an excise tax on the sale or use of energy but the imposition of the excise tax on the sale or use of energy in the law is contingent upon the enactment of an ordinance of the municipality in question. In order for the municipality to properly impose such excise tax the municipality must follow all of the provisions of O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 13, Article 6, one (1) provision of which is the enactment of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-242. - Definitions. 
Dealer shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Energy shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Local sales and use tax shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Purchaser shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-243. - Energy excise tax imposed. 
(a)	In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. Title 38, Chapter 13, Article 6, there is imposed within the territorial limits of the City of Palmetto, an excise tax on the sale or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. Title 38, Chapter 8, Article 1, but for the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(b)	The sales or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 8, Article 1, but for the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2 includes, but is not limited to, the items listed in subsection (e) of the same Code section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-244. - Energy excise tax rate and phase-in. 
(a)	The rate of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be phased in over a four-year period as directed by O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112(a)(3) and 48-13-112(b) and as set forth below: 
(1)	For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the city that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(2)	For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to fifty (50) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the city that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(3)	For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to seventy-five (75) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the city that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and 
(4)	On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to one hundred (100) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the city that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(b)	In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the territorial limits of the city, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in subsections (a)(1), (2), and (3) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in subsection (a)(4) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016 limitation in that subsection (a)(4). 
(c)	Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the city shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the city, but in no event more than two (2) percent. 
(d)	In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the city decreases from two (2) percent to one (1) percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. 
(e)	In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the city increases from one (1) percent to two (2) percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-245. - Energy excise tax imposition, remittance and recovery. 
(a)	The excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be imposed at the time and be recoverable as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(b)	The excise tax shall be a debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(c)	The dealer collecting the excise tax shall remit the excise tax to the city if the city is the governing authority imposing the excise tax as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(d)	Every dealer subject to an excise tax under this article shall be liable for the excise tax at an applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of the excise taxes collected from the purchasers, whichever is greater as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-246. - Exemption certificates. 
(a)	The governing authority of the city, or the collecting officer appointed under this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the city and to ascertain whether such purchasers have completed a uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser under the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-32.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)	An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue. The energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed under this article if a purchaser has failed to submit the uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue to such energy provider. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-247. - Commencement of collections and due date. 
(a)	The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective on January 1, 2013. 
(b)	The excise tax levied pursuant to this article shall be imposed only at the time that sales and use tax on the sale and use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(c)	The excise tax shall be due and payable in the same manner as would otherwise be required under O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 8, Article 1. 
(d)	All sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month shall be due and payable to the City of Palmetto monthly on or before the twentieth day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-248. - Expenditure of proceeds. 
The proceeds of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall not be subject to any use or expenditure requirements provided for under any of the local sales and use taxes but shall be authorized to be expended in the same manner as otherwise would have been required under such local sales and use taxes or may be expended for any lawful purpose as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). Any proceeds received by the city pursuant to this article shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-249. - Termination of municipal excise tax. 
(a)	If the city has levied and collected an excise tax within the corporate limits of municipality under this article because the county in which the city is located has refused or failed to enter into an intergovernmental agreement with each municipality wishing to participate in such excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(a)(1) and then the county determines to commence proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2), then the excise tax levied and collected by the municipality shall cease to the extent as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2). 
(b)	If the county has commenced proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2) and the excise tax levied and collected by the municipality has terminated and the municipality has chosen to participate in the county excise tax, then this article shall remain effective for the purposes of O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 13, Article 6, and particularly for the rates required by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 12-250. - Administrative provisions and audit. 
(a)	The city governing authority shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)	The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. 
(c)	The collecting officer, or designee, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of and locations within the city of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax to the energy dealer under this article. 
(d)	As part by the audit report required by O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-4-2013) 
Secs. 12-251—12-259. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS OR GEMS 

Sec. 12-260. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases when used herein shall be construed as follows: 
Dealer in precious metals or gems means: 
(1)	Any person engaged in the business of purchasing precious metals or gems or goods made from precious metals or gems from persons other than manufacturers, manufacturers' representatives, or other dealers in precious metals or gems; or 
(2)	A person engaged in any other business if, in conjunction with such business, precious metals or gems or goods made from precious metals or gems are purchased from persons or sources other than manufacturers, manufacturers' representatives, or other dealers in precious metals or gems where such purchase is for resale in its original form or as changed by remounting, melting, re-forming, remolding, or recasting or for resale as scrap or in bulk. 
Gems means any precious or semiprecious stone which is cut and polished. 
Nonpermanent location means any location designed to be used to conduct the aforementioned business, in any movable vehicle, and temporary and movable structure, including, but not limited to, vans, mobile homes, trailers, hotels and motels, lodges, or any similar nonpermanent structure designed by applicant to be used to conduct said business for a limited or specific time. Applications for businesses under this article at such locations shall not be accepted. 
Numismatic coins means coins whose value as collectors' items exceeds the value of the content of the precious metals in the coins. 
Permanent location means a business domiciled within a properly constructed building which must be located within a properly zoned area, according to the city's zoning ordinance. 
Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association, or any other legal entity however organized. 
Precious metals means gold, silver, or platinum or any alloy containing gold, silver, or platinum. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-261. - Registration required; application contents; application approval fees. 
(a)	No person shall engage in business as a dealer in precious metals or gems within the municipal limits of the City of Palmetto without first obtaining from the city an occupation tax certificate and registering with the city to operate as a dealer in precious metals or gems. 
(b)	The application for registration to operate a business as a dealer in precious metals or gems shall be promulgated by the city administrator. 
(c)	The application for said registration shall be in writing and shall be sworn to or affirmed by the applicant. The application shall contain, but not be limited to: 
(1)	The precise location from which the proposes business is to operate; 
(2)	The full name, address, phone number, date of birth and Social Security number of the applicant and any other persons having an ownership interest in the proposed business; 
(3)	The names, addresses, and ages of all officers of any publicly held corporation holding an interest in the proposed business and their titles; 
(4)	The full name, address, phone number, date of birth and Social Security number of all employees to be employed in the proposed business; 
(5)	Photographs, fingerprints and any other information deemed necessary for a background investigation by the Police Department of the City of Palmetto; and 
(6)	Any such other information as deemed necessary by the mayor and council for the City of Palmetto or the city administrator. 
(d)	All applications for registration under this article shall be accompanied by the tendering of a regulatory fee as set out in a schedule of fees adopted by the mayor and council. Said regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-262. - Processing of application. 
Review of an application to register as a dealer in precious metals or gems shall be conducted by the city administrator. The Police Chief for the City of Palmetto shall determine whether the applicant or any of their employees has ever been convicted of any felony, any crime involving larceny, burglary or theft of any description, as defined in the Official Code of Georgia, or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-263. - Method of maintaining records. 
(a)	Every dealer in precious metals or gems shall maintain a book, in permanent form, in which shall be entered in legible English at the time of each purchase of precious metals or gems or goods containing precious metals or gems, the following information: 
(1)	The date and time of the purchase transaction; 
(2)	The name of the person making the purchase from the seller; 
(3)	The name, age and address of the seller of the item(s) purchases and the distinctive number from such seller's driver's license or other similar identification card containing a photo of the seller; 
(4)	A clear and accurate identification and description of the purchased goods, including the serial numbers, model numbers or other numbers, and any identifying marks inscribed thereon; 
(5)	The price paid for the goods purchased; 
(6)	The number of the check issued for the purchase price, if the payment is made by check; and 
(5)	The signature of the seller. 
(b)	The permanent record book required herein shall be maintained for each purchase of precious metals or gems or goods made from precious metals or gems for a period of four (4) years. Entries shall appear in chronological order in ink. No blank lines may be left between entries. No obliteration, alterations, or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. The book and all precious metals or gems and goods containing precious metals or gems shall be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer at all times. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-264. - Required daily written report. 
Every dealer in precious metals or gems shall make a daily report in writing to the Police Department of the City of Palmetto of all precious metals or gems or goods containing precious metals or gems purchased during the twenty-four (24) hours ending at 9:00 p.m. on the date of the report. The reports shall be on forms or on duplicate invoices as may be prescribed or approved the police department. The reports shall be legible and mailed or delivered to the police department prior to 10:00 a.m. on the day following the date of the report. In addition to any other information required by the police department, the reports shall include the name and address of the registered dealer, the date of transaction, a description and amount of the precious metals or gems or goods containing precious metals or gems purchased, and the name and address of the person from whom purchased. The police department may promulgate rules and regulations consistent with this section to require the proper enforcement thereof. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-265. - Holding period. 
Any dealer who acquires used valuables in the course of business shall hold these items for at least ten (10) days before disposing of them by sale, transfer, shipment, grinding down, melting, or otherwise changing the original appearance of the item. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed as to prevent any dealer from storing such items off the business premises, or placing such items in the hands of any bank or security company for the purpose of safekeeping. However, any dealer storing such items off the premises shall produce such items for inspection within twelve (12) hours following the demand of any officer of the police department. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-266. - Hours of operation. 
The hours within which dealers in precious metals or gems may keep open their place of business shall be from 7:00 a.m. until 9:00 p.m. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-267. - Unlawful activities. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any dealer in precious metals or gems or any agent or employee of a dealer in precious metals or gems who makes purchases of precious metals or gems or goods containing precious metals or gems to: 
(1)	Make any false statement in the registration provided for by this article; 
(2)	Fail to maintain and make entries in the permanent record book as required by section 12-263 of this article; 
(3)	Make any false entries therein; 
(4)	Falsify, obliterate, destroy or remove from the place of business such permanent record book; 
(5)	Fail to submit daily reports as required by section 12-264 of this article; 
(6)	Refuse to allow a duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such permanent book or any precious metals or goods containing precious metals in his or her possession; 
(7)	Sell, exchange, or remove from the legal possession of the buyer, or to alter the form of, any precious metals or gems or goods containing precious metals or gems purchased by remounting, melting, cutting up, or otherwise altering the original form until at least seven (7) calendar days have elapsed from the time of purchase or acquisition; or 
(8)	Purchase any precious metals or gems from any person under seventeen (17) years of age. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or transact business as a dealer in precious metals or gems without first registering as required by this article. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any dealer in precious metals or gems to purchase precious metals in a melted or smelted state unless the purchase is from a registered dealer in precious metals or gems. 
(d)	If a law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that precious metals or gems have been stolen, he or she may give notice in writing to the dealer to retain the precious metals or gems for an additional fifteen (15) days; and it shall be unlawful for the dealer to dispose of the property unless the notice is revoked in writing within the fifteen-day period. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-268. - Suspension or revocation of registration. 
Any registration issued pursuant to this article may be suspended or revoked upon the following grounds: 
(1)	Misrepresentation of any information in the original or renewal application for any registration authorized by this article; 
(2)	The conviction of the registered dealer for a felony, the violation of any criminal law involving larceny, burglary or theft of any description as defined in the Official Code of Georgia, or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; and 
(3)	The conviction of the registered dealer for a violation of any part of section 12-267(a) of this article. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Sec. 12-269. - Notice and hearing. 
(a)	No registration which has been issued to any person pursuant to this article shall be suspended or revoked except upon one (1) or more of the grounds stated in section 12-268 and until after the registered dealer has been notified by the city administrator. 
(b)	Where it is reported to the city administrator that a registered dealer is engaged in unlawful activities, a preliminary investigation shall be conducted by the city administrator in order to attempt to determine whether there is a basis for the reports. If the city administrator's preliminary investigation reveals that there may be a basis for revocation and suspension of the registration, the registered dealer shall be notified to appear before the city administrator and show cause on a date certain why his or her registration should not be revoked or suspended. The registered dealer may appear in person at the hearing or be represented by counsel. At the conclusion of the hearing, the city administrator, based upon evidence submitted at the hearing, shall enter an order making a finding of fact and then: 
(1)	Find that the evidence does not authorize revocation or suspension; 
(2)	Issue a warning to the registered dealer; 
(3)	Suspend the registration and probate suspension; 
(4)	Revoke the registration and probate revocation; 
(5)	Suspend the registration; or 
(6)	Revoke the registration. 
(c)	Within five (5) days from the date of the order from the city administrator, the registered dealer may appeal the decision by filing a notice of appeal with the mayor and council. The city administrator shall schedule a hearing before the mayor and council and notify the registered dealer of the time and date of the hearing. At the conclusion of the hearing, the mayor and council shall enter an order which contains therein a finding of fact and a decision to: 
(1)	Find in favor of the registered dealer; 
(2)	Issue a warning to registered dealer; 
(3)	Suspend the registration and probate suspension; 
(4)	Revoke the registration and probate revocation; 
(5)	Suspend the registration; 
(6)	Revoke the registration; and/or 
(7)	Take any other appropriate action regarding the registered dealer. 
( Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-2-2015 ) 
Chapter 13 - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1, adopted Sept. 4, 2012, repealed former Ch. 13, §§ 13-1—13-105, and enacted a new Ch. 13 as set out herein. The former chapter pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1977, § 7-1255. 
Charter reference— Power to regulate businesses, § 27.1 et seq. 
Cross reference— Business license taxes and fees, § 12-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; giving massages in places used for lewdness, prostitution, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-6-17. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charge, either directly or indirectly, refers to a salary, commission, gratuity or other remuneration as paid or made available to a massage therapist administering massages as a primary or incidental activity resulting from such payment a charge, fee, dues or other payment for the purpose of receiving any service or use of an establishment which provides for the payor the opportunity to obtain a massage. 
Genitals means the external sexual organs. 
Health certificate means a certificate from a regular practicing medical doctor showing that the person named therein has been examined and is free from any infectious or communicable disease. 
Massage means the act or art of treating the human body or any part thereof by rubbing, kneading, tapping, compression, vibration, application of friction or percussion or like ministrations to stimulate circulation or increase suppleness for a charge, direct or indirect. 
Massage establishment means any building, room, place or establishment where massages are practiced upon the human body for a charge, either directly or indirectly, by a person, whether with or without the use of mechanical, therapeutic or bathing devices, whether primary or an incidental activity of the establishment in which the massage is performed. 
Massage establishment license means that document issued by the city to an establishment where massages are furnished. 
Massage therapist means a person who administers massages. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 13-2. - Exceptions.
